content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
As a result, the Salmonella Reference Laboratory is identifying strains from human inf ctions, animal diseases (including poultry), and from various foodstuffs.
The cultures are investigated both as to their biochemical reactions und their antigenic structure. Reports are sent back to the laboratory, and are therefore couched in scientific term , giving details of antigenic structure and any bio- chenicul or other results which are worthy of comment.
-
Cultures which, on investigation, are not salmonellae, have a full report giving all the biochemical and serological resactions found, together with the interpretation of these findings. This method of reporting has been u most valuable means of disseminating technical knowledge in an informal way.
The Standarde Laboratory, which issues roagents for salmonellu identification, nas been in existence since 1917. Occasionally special sera aro isqued. Normally type strains are issued by the National Collection of Type Cultures, but special cultures are occasionally issued by the Salmonella Reference Laboratory. The Salmonella Reference Laboratory investigates the sora of man and animals for the presence of salmonella ag lutinins. This is done very rarely und only in special circumstances.
The full identification of new serotypes of salmonella is made and the results reported in the press. But before publication, culturas are sent to the Inter- national Salmonella and Escherichia Centre nt Copenhagen, and to the Communicable Disease Centre, Atlanta, for checking.
The Salmonella Reference Laboratory works in close liaison with the Epidemio- logical Research In oratory at Colindale. Hospital and public Health Laboratories throughout England and Wales report all cases and outbreaks of salmonella Infection each week to the optuemiological unit, Col ndale, which circulate this information, together with other information, to all inboratori s. Final reports on outbreaks are sent to the salmonella Reference Laboratory. When all the inform tion is available this soterial is sorted and returned to the epidemiological unit for inclusion in the annual report on food poisoning and salmonello info
63
As the Salmonella Reference Inbor tory is in close touch with
1212 16 WVet FLINTY
toademia Historica and food laboratories, it is sometimes possible to advise on suitable investigations

As a result, the Salmonella Reference Laboratory is identifying strains from human inf ctions, animal diseases (including poultry), and from various foodstuffs.

The cultures are investigated both as to their biochemical reactions und their antigenic structure. Reports are sent back to the laboratory, and are therefore couched in scientific term , giving details of antigenic structure and any bio- chenicul or other results which are worthy of comment.

Cultures which, on investigation, are not salmonellae, have a full report giving all the biochemical and serological resactions found, together with the interpretation of these findings. This method of reporting has been u most valuable means of disseminating technical knowledge in an informal way.

The Standarde Laboratory, which issues roagents for salmonellu identification, nas been in existence since 1917. Occasionally special sera aro isqued. Normally type strains are issued by the National Collection of Type Cultures, but special cultures are occasionally issued by the Salmonella Reference Laboratory. The Salmonella Reference Laboratory investigates the sora of man and animals for the presence of salmonella ag lutinins. This is done very rarely und only in special circumstances.

The full identification of new serotypes of salmonella is made and the results reported in the press. But before publication, culturas are sent to the Inter- national Salmonella and Escherichia Centre nt Copenhagen, and to the Communicable Disease Centre, Atlanta, for checking.

The Salmonella Reference Laboratory works in close liaison with the Epidemio- logical Research In oratory at Colindale. Hospital and public Health Laboratories throughout England and Wales report all cases and outbreaks of salmonella Infection each week to the optuemiological unit, Col ndale, which circulate this information, together with other information, to all inboratori s. Final reports on outbreaks are sent to the salmonella Reference Laboratory. When all the inform tion is available this soterial is sorted and returned to the epidemiological unit for inclusion in the annual report on food poisoning and salmonello info
